column2: Their substance we consider absolutely and in relation to corporeal things.
column3: Their substance we consider absolutely and in relation to corporeal things.

column2: Concerning their substance absolutely considered, there are five points of inquiry:
column3: Concerning their substance absolutely considered, there are five points of inquiry:

column2: (1) Whether there is any entirely spiritual creature, altogether incorporeal?
column3: (one) Whether there is any entirely spiritual creature, altogether incorporeal?

column2: (2) Supposing that an angel is such, we ask whether it is composed of matter and form?
column3: (two) Supposing that an angel is such, we ask whether it is composed of matter and form?

column2: (3) We ask concerning their number.
column3: (three) We ask concerning their number.

column2: (4) Of their difference from each other.
column3: (four) Of their difference from each other.

column2: (5) Of their immortality or incorruptibility. _______________________
column3: (five) Of their immortality or incorruptibility. , blank ,

column2: FIRST ARTICLE [I, Q. 50, Art. 1]
column3: FIRST ARTICLE [I, q fifty, Art. one]

column2: Whether an Angel Is Altogether Incorporeal?
column3: Whether an Angel Is Altogether Incorporeal?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that an angel is not entirely incorporeal. For what is incorporeal only as regards ourselves, and not in relation to God, is not absolutely incorporeal.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that an angel is not entirely incorporeal. For what is incorporeal only as regards ourselves, and not in relation to God, is not absolutely incorporeal.

column2: But Damascene says (De Fide Orth.
column3: But Damascene says (De Fide Orth.

column2: ii) that "an angel is said to be incorporeal and immaterial as regards us; but compared to God it is corporeal and material. Therefore he is not simply incorporeal."
column3: ii) that "an angel is said to be incorporeal and immaterial as regards us; but compared to God it is corporeal and material. Therefore he is not simply incorporeal."

column2: Obj. 2: Further, nothing is moved except a body, as the Philosopher says (Phys. vi, text 32).
column3: o b j. two: Further, nothing is moved except a body, as the Philosopher says (Phys. vi, text thirty two).

column2: But Damascene says (De Fide Orth. ii) that "an angel is an ever movable intellectual substance." Therefore an angel is a corporeal substance.
column3: But Damascene says (De Fide Orth. ii) that "an angel is an ever movable intellectual substance." Therefore an angel is a corporeal substance.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, Ambrose says (De Spir.
column3: o b j. three: Further, Ambrose says (De Spir.

column2: Sanct. i, 7): "Every creature is limited within its own nature." But to be limited belongs to bodies.
column3: Sanct. i, seven): "Every creature is limited within its own nature." But to be limited belongs to bodies.

column2: Therefore, every creature is corporeal.
column3: Therefore, every creature is corporeal.

column2: Now angels are God's creatures, as appears from Ps. 148:2: "Praise ye" the Lord, "all His angels"; and, farther on (verse 4), "For He spoke, and they were made; He commanded, and they were created." Therefore angels are corporeal.
column3: Now angels are God's creatures, as appears from p's. one hundred forty eight to two: "Praise ye" the Lord, "all His angels"; and, farther on (verse four), "For He spoke, and they were made; He commanded, and they were created." Therefore angels are corporeal.

column2: _On the contrary,_ It is said (Ps. 103:4): "Who makes His angels spirits."
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore It is said (p's. one hundred three to four): "Who makes His angels spirits."

column2: _I answer that,_ There must be some incorporeal creatures.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore There must be some incorporeal creatures.

column2: For what is principally intended by God in creatures is good, and this consists in assimilation to God Himself.
column3: For what is principally intended by God in creatures is good, and this consists in assimilation to God Himself.

column2: And the perfect assimilation of an effect to a cause is accomplished when the effect imitates the cause according to that whereby the cause produces the effect; as heat makes heat.
column3: And the perfect assimilation of an effect to a cause is accomplished when the effect imitates the cause according to that whereby the cause produces the effect; as heat makes heat.

column2: Now, God produces the creature by His intellect and will (Q. 14, A. 8; Q. 19, A. 4).
column3: Now, God produces the creature by His intellect and will (Q. fourteen, a eight; q nineteen, a four).

column2: Hence the perfection of the universe requires that there should be intellectual creatures.
column3: Hence the perfection of the universe requires that there should be intellectual creatures.

column2: Now intelligence cannot be the action of a body, nor of any corporeal faculty; for every body is limited to "here" and "now." Hence the perfection of the universe requires the existence of an incorporeal creature.
column3: Now intelligence cannot be the action of a body, nor of any corporeal faculty; for every body is limited to "here" and "now." Hence the perfection of the universe requires the existence of an incorporeal creature.

column2: The ancients, however, not properly realizing the force of intelligence, and failing to make a proper distinction between sense and intellect, thought that nothing existed in the world but what could be apprehended by sense and imagination.
column3: The ancients, however, not properly realizing the force of intelligence, and failing to make a proper distinction between sense and intellect, thought that nothing existed in the world but what could be apprehended by sense and imagination.

column2: And because bodies alone fall under imagination, they supposed that no being existed except bodies, as the Philosopher observes (Phys.
column3: And because bodies alone fall under imagination, they supposed that no being existed except bodies, as the Philosopher observes (Phys.

column2: iv, text 52,57). Thence came the error of the Sadducees, who said there was no spirit (Acts 23:8).
column3: i v, text fifty two,fifty seven). Thence came the error of the Sadducees, who said there was no spirit (acts chapter twenty three verse eight).

column2: But the very fact that intellect is above sense is a reasonable proof that there are some incorporeal things comprehensible by the intellect alone.
column3: But the very fact that intellect is above sense is a reasonable proof that there are some incorporeal things comprehensible by the intellect alone.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: Incorporeal substances rank between God and corporeal creatures.
column3: Reply o b j. one: Incorporeal substances rank between God and corporeal creatures.

column2: Now the medium compared to one extreme appears to be the other extreme, as what is tepid compared to heat seems to be cold; and thus it is said that angels, compared to God, are material and corporeal, not, however, as if anything corporeal existed in them.
column3: Now the medium compared to one extreme appears to be the other extreme, as what is tepid compared to heat seems to be cold; and thus it is said that angels, compared to God, are material and corporeal, not, however, as if anything corporeal existed in them.

column2: Reply Obj. 2: Movement is there taken in the sense in which it is applied to intelligence and will.
column3: Reply o b j. two: Movement is there taken in the sense in which it is applied to intelligence and will.

column2: Therefore an angel is called an ever mobile substance, because he is ever actually intelligent, and not as if he were sometimes actually and sometimes potentially, as we are.
column3: Therefore an angel is called an ever mobile substance, because he is ever actually intelligent, and not as if he were sometimes actually and sometimes potentially, as we are.

column2: Hence it is clear that the objection rests on an equivocation.
column3: Hence it is clear that the objection rests on an equivocation.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: To be circumscribed by local limits belongs to bodies only; whereas to be circumscribed by essential limits belongs to all creatures, both corporeal and spiritual.
column3: Reply o b j. three: To be circumscribed by local limits belongs to bodies only; whereas to be circumscribed by essential limits belongs to all creatures, both corporeal and spiritual.

column2: Hence Ambrose says (De Spir. Sanct. i, 7) that "although some things are not contained in corporeal place, still they are none the less circumscribed by their substance." _______________________
column3: Hence Ambrose says (De Spir. Sanct. i, seven) that "although some things are not contained in corporeal place, still they are none the less circumscribed by their substance." , blank ,

column2: SECOND ARTICLE [I, Q. 50, Art. 2]
column3: SECOND ARTICLE [I, q fifty, Art. two]

column2: Whether an Angel Is Composed of Matter and Form?
column3: Whether an Angel Is Composed of Matter and Form?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that an angel is composed of matter and form.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that an angel is composed of matter and form.

column2: For everything which is contained under any genus is composed of the genus, and of the difference which added to the genus makes the species.
column3: For everything which is contained under any genus is composed of the genus, and of the difference which added to the genus makes the species.

column2: But the genus comes from the matter, and the difference from the form (Metaph. xiii, text 6).
column3: But the genus comes from the matter, and the difference from the form (Metaph. x i i i, text six).

column2: Therefore everything which is in a genus is composed of matter and form.
column3: Therefore everything which is in a genus is composed of matter and form.

column2: But an angel is in the genus of substance.
column3: But an angel is in the genus of substance.

column2: Therefore he is composed of matter and form.
column3: Therefore he is composed of matter and form.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, wherever the properties of matter exist, there is matter.
column3: o b j. two: Further, wherever the properties of matter exist, there is matter.

column2: Now the properties of matter are to receive and to substand; whence Boethius says (De Trin.) that "a simple form cannot be a subject": and the above properties are found in the angel.
column3: Now the properties of matter are to receive and to substand; whence Boethius says (De Trin.) that "a simple form cannot be a subject": and the above properties are found in the angel.

column2: Therefore an angel is composed of matter and form.
column3: Therefore an angel is composed of matter and form.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, form is act.
column3: o b j. three: Further, form is act.

column2: So what is form only is pure act.
column3: So what is form only is pure act.

column2: But an angel is not pure act, for this belongs to God alone.
column3: But an angel is not pure act, for this belongs to God alone.

column2: Therefore an angel is not form only, but has a form in matter.
column3: Therefore an angel is not form only, but has a form in matter.

column2: Obj. 4: Further, form is properly limited and perfected by matter.
column3: o b j. four: Further, form is properly limited and perfected by matter.

column2: So the form which is not in matter is an infinite form.
column3: So the form which is not in matter is an infinite form.

column2: But the form of an angel is not infinite, for every creature is finite.
column3: But the form of an angel is not infinite, for every creature is finite.

column2: Therefore the form of an angel is in matter.
column3: Therefore the form of an angel is in matter.

column2: _On the contrary,_ Dionysius says (Div.
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore Dionysius says (d i v.

column2: Nom. iv): "The first creatures are understood to be as immaterial as they are incorporeal."
column3: Nom. i v): "The first creatures are understood to be as immaterial as they are incorporeal."

column2: _I answer that,_ Some assert that the angels are composed of matter and form; which opinion Avicebron endeavored to establish in his book of the _Fount of Life._ For he supposes that whatever things are distinguished by the intellect are really distinct.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore Some assert that the angels are composed of matter and form; which opinion Avicebron endeavored to establish in his book of the underscore Fount of Life.underscore For he supposes that whatever things are distinguished by the intellect are really distinct.

column2: Now as regards incorporeal substance, the intellect apprehends that which distinguishes it from corporeal substance, and that which it has in common with it.
column3: Now as regards incorporeal substance, the intellect apprehends that which distinguishes it from corporeal substance, and that which it has in common with it.

column2: Hence he concludes that what distinguishes incorporeal from corporeal substance is a kind of form to it, and whatever is subject to this distinguishing form, as it were something common, is its matter.
column3: Hence he concludes that what distinguishes incorporeal from corporeal substance is a kind of form to it, and whatever is subject to this distinguishing form, as it were something common, is its matter.

column2: Therefore, he asserts the universal matter of spiritual and corporeal things is the same; so that it must be understood that the form of incorporeal substance is impressed in the matter of spiritual things, in the same way as the form of quantity is impressed in the matter of corporeal things.
column3: Therefore, he asserts the universal matter of spiritual and corporeal things is the same; so that it must be understood that the form of incorporeal substance is impressed in the matter of spiritual things, in the same way as the form of quantity is impressed in the matter of corporeal things.

column2: But one glance is enough to show that there cannot be one matter of spiritual and of corporeal things.
column3: But one glance is enough to show that there cannot be one matter of spiritual and of corporeal things.

column2: For it is not possible that a spiritual and a corporeal form should be received into the same part of matter, otherwise one and the same thing would be corporeal and spiritual.
column3: For it is not possible that a spiritual and a corporeal form should be received into the same part of matter, otherwise one and the same thing would be corporeal and spiritual.

column2: Hence it would follow that one part of matter receives the corporeal form, and another receives the spiritual form.
column3: Hence it would follow that one part of matter receives the corporeal form, and another receives the spiritual form.

column2: Matter, however, is not divisible into parts except as regarded under quantity; and without quantity substance is indivisible, as Aristotle says (Phys. i, text 15).
column3: Matter, however, is not divisible into parts except as regarded under quantity; and without quantity substance is indivisible, as Aristotle says (Phys. i, text fifteen).

column2: Therefore it would follow that the matter of spiritual things is subject to quantity; which cannot be.
column3: Therefore it would follow that the matter of spiritual things is subject to quantity; which cannot be.

column2: Therefore it is impossible that corporeal and spiritual things should have the same matter.
column3: Therefore it is impossible that corporeal and spiritual things should have the same matter.

column2: It is, further, impossible for an intellectual substance to have any kind of matter.
column3: It is, further, impossible for an intellectual substance to have any kind of matter.

column2: For the operation belonging to anything is according to the mode of its substance.
column3: For the operation belonging to anything is according to the mode of its substance.

column2: Now to understand is an altogether immaterial operation, as appears from its object, whence any act receives its species and nature.
column3: Now to understand is an altogether immaterial operation, as appears from its object, whence any act receives its species and nature.

column2: For a thing is understood according to its degree of immateriality; because forms that exist in matter are individual forms which the intellect cannot apprehend as such.
column3: For a thing is understood according to its degree of immateriality; because forms that exist in matter are individual forms which the intellect cannot apprehend as such.

column2: Hence it must be that every individual substance is altogether immaterial.
column3: Hence it must be that every individual substance is altogether immaterial.

column2: But things distinguished by the intellect are not necessarily distinguished in reality; because the intellect does not apprehend things according to their mode, but according to its own mode.
column3: But things distinguished by the intellect are not necessarily distinguished in reality; because the intellect does not apprehend things according to their mode, but according to its own mode.

column2: Hence material things which are below our intellect exist in our intellect in a simpler mode than they exist in themselves.
column3: Hence material things which are below our intellect exist in our intellect in a simpler mode than they exist in themselves.

column2: Angelic substances, on the other hand, are above our intellect; and hence our intellect cannot attain to apprehend them, as they are in themselves, but by its own mode, according as it apprehends composite things; and in this way also it apprehends God (Q. 3).
column3: Angelic substances, on the other hand, are above our intellect; and hence our intellect cannot attain to apprehend them, as they are in themselves, but by its own mode, according as it apprehends composite things; and in this way also it apprehends God (Q. three).

column2: Reply Obj. 1: It is difference which constitutes the species.
column3: Reply o b j. one: It is difference which constitutes the species.

column2: Now everything is constituted in a species according as it is determined to some special grade of being because "the species of things are like numbers," which differ by addition and subtraction of unity, as the Philosopher says (Metaph. viii, text 10).
column3: Now everything is constituted in a species according as it is determined to some special grade of being because "the species of things are like numbers," which differ by addition and subtraction of unity, as the Philosopher says (Metaph. viii, text ten).

column2: But in material things there is one thing which determines to a special grade, and that is the form; and another thing which is determined, and this is the matter; and hence from the latter the genus is derived, and from the former the "difference." Whereas in immaterial things there is no separate determinator and thing determined; each thing by its own self holds a determinate grade in being; and therefore in them genus and "difference" are not derived from different things, but from one and the same.
column3: But in material things there is one thing which determines to a special grade, and that is the form; and another thing which is determined, and this is the matter; and hence from the latter the genus is derived, and from the former the "difference." Whereas in immaterial things there is no separate determinator and thing determined; each thing by its own self holds a determinate grade in being; and therefore in them genus and "difference" are not derived from different things, but from one and the same.

column2: Nevertheless, this differs in our mode of conception; for, inasmuch as our intellect considers it as indeterminate, it derives the idea of their genus; and inasmuch as it considers it determinately, it derives the idea of their "difference."
column3: Nevertheless, this differs in our mode of conception; for, inasmuch as our intellect considers it as indeterminate, it derives the idea of their genus; and inasmuch as it considers it determinately, it derives the idea of their "difference."

column2: Reply Obj. 2: This reason is given in the book on the _Fount of Life,_ and it would be cogent, supposing that the receptive mode of the intellect and of matter were the same.
column3: Reply o b j. two: This reason is given in the book on the underscore Fount of Life,underscore and it would be cogent, supposing that the receptive mode of the intellect and of matter were the same.

column2: But this is clearly false. For matter receives the form, that thereby it may be constituted in some species, either of air, or of fire, or of something else.
column3: But this is clearly false. For matter receives the form, that thereby it may be constituted in some species, either of air, or of fire, or of something else.

column2: But the intellect does not receive the form in the same way; otherwise the opinion of Empedocles (De Anima i, 5, text 26) would be true, to the effect that we know earth by earth, and fire by fire.
column3: But the intellect does not receive the form in the same way; otherwise the opinion of Empedocles (De Anima i, five, text twenty six) would be true, to the effect that we know earth by earth, and fire by fire.

column2: But the intelligible form is in the intellect according to the very nature of a form; for as such is it so known by the intellect.
column3: But the intelligible form is in the intellect according to the very nature of a form; for as such is it so known by the intellect.

column2: Hence such a way of receiving is not that of matter, but of an immaterial substance.
column3: Hence such a way of receiving is not that of matter, but of an immaterial substance.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: Although there is no composition of matter and form in an angel, yet there is act and potentiality.
column3: Reply o b j. three: Although there is no composition of matter and form in an angel, yet there is act and potentiality.

column2: And this can be made evident if we consider the nature of material things which contain a twofold composition.
column3: And this can be made evident if we consider the nature of material things which contain a twofold composition.

column2: The first is that of form and matter, whereby the nature is constituted.
column3: The first is that of form and matter, whereby the nature is constituted.

column2: Such a composite nature is not its own existence but existence is its act.
column3: Such a composite nature is not its own existence but existence is its act.

column2: Hence the nature itself is related to its own existence as potentiality to act.
column3: Hence the nature itself is related to its own existence as potentiality to act.

column2: Therefore if there be no matter, and supposing that the form itself subsists without matter, there nevertheless still remains the relation of the form to its very existence, as of potentiality to act.
column3: Therefore if there be no matter, and supposing that the form itself subsists without matter, there nevertheless still remains the relation of the form to its very existence, as of potentiality to act.

column2: And such a kind of composition is understood to be in the angels; and this is what some say, that an angel is composed of, "whereby he is," and "what is," or "existence," and "what is," as Boethius says.
column3: And such a kind of composition is understood to be in the angels; and this is what some say, that an angel is composed of, "whereby he is," and "what is," or "existence," and "what is," as Boethius says.

column2: For "what is," is the form itself subsisting; and the existence itself is whereby the substance is; as the running is whereby the runner runs. But in God "existence" and "what is" are not different as was explained above (Q. 3, A. 4).
column3: For "what is," is the form itself subsisting; and the existence itself is whereby the substance is; as the running is whereby the runner runs. But in God "existence" and "what is" are not different as was explained above (Q. three, a four).

column2: Hence God alone is pure act.
column3: Hence God alone is pure act.

column2: Reply Obj. 4: Every creature is simply finite, inasmuch as its existence is not absolutely subsisting, but is limited to some nature to which it belongs.
column3: Reply o b j. four: Every creature is simply finite, inasmuch as its existence is not absolutely subsisting, but is limited to some nature to which it belongs.

column2: But there is nothing against a creature being considered relatively infinite.
column3: But there is nothing against a creature being considered relatively infinite.

column2: Material creatures are infinite on the part of matter, but finite in their form, which is limited by the matter which receives it.
column3: Material creatures are infinite on the part of matter, but finite in their form, which is limited by the matter which receives it.

column2: But immaterial created substances are finite in their being; whereas they are infinite in the sense that their forms are not received in anything else; as if we were to say, for example, that whiteness existing separate is infinite as regards the nature of whiteness, forasmuch as it is not contracted to any one subject; while its "being" is finite as determined to some one special nature.
column3: But immaterial created substances are finite in their being; whereas they are infinite in the sense that their forms are not received in anything else; as if we were to say, for example, that whiteness existing separate is infinite as regards the nature of whiteness, forasmuch as it is not contracted to any one subject; while its "being" is finite as determined to some one special nature.

column2: Whence it is said (De Causis, prop. 16) that "intelligence is finite from above," as receiving its being from above itself, and is "infinite from below," as not received in any matter. _______________________
column3: Whence it is said (De Causis, prop. sixteen) that "intelligence is finite from above," as receiving its being from above itself, and is "infinite from below," as not received in any matter. , blank ,

column2: THIRD ARTICLE [I, Q. 50, Art. 3]
column3: THIRD ARTICLE [I, q fifty, Art. three]

column2: Whether the Angels Exist in Any Great Number?
column3: Whether the Angels Exist in Any Great Number?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that the angels are not in great numbers. For number is a species of quantity, and follows the division of a continuous body.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that the angels are not in great numbers. For number is a species of quantity, and follows the division of a continuous body.

column2: But this cannot be in the angels, since they are incorporeal, as was shown above (A. 1).
column3: But this cannot be in the angels, since they are incorporeal, as was shown above (A. one).

column2: Therefore the angels cannot exist in any great number.
column3: Therefore the angels cannot exist in any great number.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, the more a thing approaches to unity, so much the less is it multiplied, as is evident in numbers.
column3: o b j. two: Further, the more a thing approaches to unity, so much the less is it multiplied, as is evident in numbers.

column2: But among other created natures the angelic nature approaches nearest to God. Therefore since God is supremely one, it seems that there is the least possible number in the angelic nature.
column3: But among other created natures the angelic nature approaches nearest to God. Therefore since God is supremely one, it seems that there is the least possible number in the angelic nature.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, the proper effect of the separate substances seems to be the movements of the heavenly bodies.
column3: o b j. three: Further, the proper effect of the separate substances seems to be the movements of the heavenly bodies.

column2: But the movements of the heavenly bodies fall within some small determined number, which we can apprehend.
column3: But the movements of the heavenly bodies fall within some small determined number, which we can apprehend.

column2: Therefore the angels are not in greater number than the movements of the heavenly bodies.
column3: Therefore the angels are not in greater number than the movements of the heavenly bodies.

column2: Obj. 4: Dionysius says (Div.
column3: o b j. four: Dionysius says (d i v.

column2: Nom. iv) that "all intelligible and intellectual substances subsist because of the rays of the divine goodness." But a ray is only multiplied according to the different things that receive it.
column3: Nom. i v) that "all intelligible and intellectual substances subsist because of the rays of the divine goodness." But a ray is only multiplied according to the different things that receive it.

column2: Now it cannot be said that their matter is receptive of an intelligible ray, since intellectual substances are immaterial, as was shown above (A. 2).
column3: Now it cannot be said that their matter is receptive of an intelligible ray, since intellectual substances are immaterial, as was shown above (A. two).

column2: Therefore it seems that the multiplication of intellectual substances can only be according to the requirements of the first bodies--that is, of the heavenly ones, so that in some way the shedding form of the aforesaid rays may be terminated in them; and hence the same conclusion is to be drawn as before.
column3: Therefore it seems that the multiplication of intellectual substances can only be according to the requirements of the first bodies-that is, of the heavenly ones, so that in some way the shedding form of the aforesaid rays may be terminated in them; and hence the same conclusion is to be drawn as before.

column2: _On the contrary,_ It is said (Dan. 7:10): "Thousands of thousands ministered to Him, and ten thousands times a hundred thousand stood before Him."
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore It is said (Dan. seven ten): "Thousands of thousands ministered to Him, and ten thousands times a hundred thousand stood before Him."

column2: _I answer that,_ There have been various opinions with regard to the number of the separate substances.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore There have been various opinions with regard to the number of the separate substances.

column2: Plato contended that the separate substances are the species of sensible things; as if we were to maintain that human nature is a separate substance of itself: and according to this view it would have to be maintained that the number of the separate substances is the number of the species of sensible things.
column3: Plato contended that the separate substances are the species of sensible things; as if we were to maintain that human nature is a separate substance of itself: and according to this view it would have to be maintained that the number of the separate substances is the number of the species of sensible things.

column2: Aristotle, however, rejects this view (Metaph. i, text 31) because matter is of the very nature of the species of sensible things.
column3: Aristotle, however, rejects this view (Metaph. i, text thirty one) because matter is of the very nature of the species of sensible things.

column2: Consequently the separate substances cannot be the exemplar species of these sensible things; but have their own fixed natures, which are higher than the natures of sensible things.
column3: Consequently the separate substances cannot be the exemplar species of these sensible things; but have their own fixed natures, which are higher than the natures of sensible things.

column2: Nevertheless Aristotle held (Metaph.
column3: Nevertheless Aristotle held (Metaph.

column2: xi, text 43) that those more perfect natures bear relation to these sensible things, as that of mover and end; and therefore he strove to find out the number of the separate substances according to the number of the first movements.
column3: xi, text forty three) that those more perfect natures bear relation to these sensible things, as that of mover and end; and therefore he strove to find out the number of the separate substances according to the number of the first movements.

column2: But since this appears to militate against the teachings of Sacred Scripture, Rabbi Moses the Jew, wishing to bring both into harmony, held that the angels, in so far as they are styled immaterial substances, are multiplied according to the number of heavenly movements or bodies, as Aristotle held (Metaph. xi, text 43); while he contended that in the Scriptures even men bearing a divine message are styled angels; and again, even the powers of natural things, which manifest God's almighty power.
column3: But since this appears to militate against the teachings of Sacred Scripture, Rabbi Moses the Jew, wishing to bring both into harmony, held that the angels, in so far as they are styled immaterial substances, are multiplied according to the number of heavenly movements or bodies, as Aristotle held (Metaph. xi, text forty three); while he contended that in the Scriptures even men bearing a divine message are styled angels; and again, even the powers of natural things, which manifest God's almighty power.

column2: It is, however, quite foreign to the custom of the Scriptures for the powers of irrational things to be designated as angels.
column3: It is, however, quite foreign to the custom of the Scriptures for the powers of irrational things to be designated as angels.

column2: Hence it must be said that the angels, even inasmuch as they are immaterial substances, exist in exceeding great number, far beyond all material multitude.
column3: Hence it must be said that the angels, even inasmuch as they are immaterial substances, exist in exceeding great number, far beyond all material multitude.

column2: This is what Dionysius says (Coel.
column3: This is what Dionysius says (Coel.

column2: Hier. xiv): "There are many blessed armies of the heavenly intelligences, surpassing the weak and limited reckoning of our material numbers." The reason whereof is this, because, since it is the perfection of the universe that God chiefly intends in the creation of things, the more perfect some things are, in so much greater an excess are they created by God.
column3: Hier. x i v): "There are many blessed armies of the heavenly intelligences, surpassing the weak and limited reckoning of our material numbers." The reason whereof is this, because, since it is the perfection of the universe that God chiefly intends in the creation of things, the more perfect some things are, in so much greater an excess are they created by God.

column2: Now, as in bodies such excess is observed in regard to their magnitude, so in things incorporeal is it observed in regard to their multitude.
column3: Now, as in bodies such excess is observed in regard to their magnitude, so in things incorporeal is it observed in regard to their multitude.

column2: We see, in fact, that incorruptible bodies, exceed corruptible bodies almost incomparably in magnitude; for the entire sphere of things active and passive is something very small in comparison with the heavenly bodies.
column3: We see, in fact, that incorruptible bodies, exceed corruptible bodies almost incomparably in magnitude; for the entire sphere of things active and passive is something very small in comparison with the heavenly bodies.

column2: Hence it is reasonable to conclude that the immaterial substances as it were incomparably exceed material substances as to multitude.
column3: Hence it is reasonable to conclude that the immaterial substances as it were incomparably exceed material substances as to multitude.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: In the angels number is not that of discrete quantity, brought about by division of what is continuous, but that which is caused by distinction of forms; according as multitude is reckoned among the transcendentals, as was said above (Q. 30, A. 3; Q. 11).
column3: Reply o b j. one: In the angels number is not that of discrete quantity, brought about by division of what is continuous, but that which is caused by distinction of forms; according as multitude is reckoned among the transcendentals, as was said above (Q. thirty, a three; q eleven).

column2: Reply Obj. 2: From the angelic nature being the nighest unto God, it must needs have least of multitude in its composition, but not so as to be found in few subjects.
column3: Reply o b j. two: From the angelic nature being the nighest unto God, it must needs have least of multitude in its composition, but not so as to be found in few subjects.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: This is Aristotle's argument (Metaph.
column3: Reply o b j. three: This is Aristotle's argument (Metaph.

column2: xii, text 44), and it would conclude necessarily if the separate substances were made for corporeal substances.
column3: x i i, text forty four), and it would conclude necessarily if the separate substances were made for corporeal substances.

column2: For thus the immaterial substances would exist to no purpose, unless some movement from them were to appear in corporeal things.
column3: For thus the immaterial substances would exist to no purpose, unless some movement from them were to appear in corporeal things.

column2: But it is not true that the immaterial substances exist on account of the corporeal, because the end is nobler than the means to the end.
column3: But it is not true that the immaterial substances exist on account of the corporeal, because the end is nobler than the means to the end.

column2: Hence Aristotle says (Metaph.
column3: Hence Aristotle says (Metaph.

column2: xii, text 44) that this is not a necessary argument, but a probable one.
column3: x i i, text forty four) that this is not a necessary argument, but a probable one.

column2: He was forced to make use of this argument, since only through sensible things can we come to know intelligible ones.
column3: He was forced to make use of this argument, since only through sensible things can we come to know intelligible ones.

column2: Reply Obj. 4: This argument comes from the opinion of such as hold that matter is the cause of the distinction of things; but this was refuted above (Q. 47, A. 1).
column3: Reply o b j. four: This argument comes from the opinion of such as hold that matter is the cause of the distinction of things; but this was refuted above (Q. forty seven, a one).

column2: Accordingly, the multiplication of the angels is not to be taken according to matter, nor according to bodies, but according to the divine wisdom devising the various orders of immaterial substances. _______________________
column3: Accordingly, the multiplication of the angels is not to be taken according to matter, nor according to bodies, but according to the divine wisdom devising the various orders of immaterial substances. , blank ,

column2: FOURTH ARTICLE [I, Q. 50, Art. 4]
column3: FOURTH ARTICLE [I, q fifty, Art. four]

column2: Whether the Angels Differ in Species?
column3: Whether the Angels Differ in Species?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that the angels do not differ in species. For since the "difference" is nobler than the 'genus,' all things which agree in what is noblest in them, agree likewise in their ultimate constitutive difference; and so they are the same according to species.
column3: Objection one: It would seem that the angels do not differ in species. For since the "difference" is nobler than the 'genus,' all things which agree in what is noblest in them, agree likewise in their ultimate constitutive difference; and so they are the same according to species.

column2: But all angels agree in what is noblest in them--that is to say, in intellectuality.
column3: But all angels agree in what is noblest in them-that is to say, in intellectuality.

column2: Therefore all the angels are of one species.
column3: Therefore all the angels are of one species.

column2: Obj. 2: Further, more and less do not change a species.
column3: o b j. two: Further, more and less do not change a species.

column2: But the angels seem to differ only from one another according to more and less--namely, as one is simpler than another, and of keener intellect.
column3: But the angels seem to differ only from one another according to more and less-namely, as one is simpler than another, and of keener intellect.

column2: Therefore the angels do not differ specifically.
column3: Therefore the angels do not differ specifically.

column2: Obj. 3: Further, soul and angel are contra-distinguished mutually from each other.
column3: o b j. three: Further, soul and angel are contra distinguished mutually from each other.

column2: But all souls are of the one species.
column3: But all souls are of the one species.

column2: So therefore are the angels.
column3: So therefore are the angels.

column2: Obj. 4: Further, the more perfect a thing is in nature, the more ought it to be multiplied.
column3: o b j. four: Further, the more perfect a thing is in nature, the more ought it to be multiplied.

column2: But this would not be so if there were but one individual under one species.
column3: But this would not be so if there were but one individual under one species.

column2: Therefore there are many angels of one species.
column3: Therefore there are many angels of one species.

column2: _On the contrary,_ In things of one species there is no such thing as "first" and "second" [prius et posterius], as the Philosopher says (Metaph. iii, text 2).
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore In things of one species there is no such thing as "first" and "second" [prius et posterius], as the Philosopher says (Metaph. iii, text two).

column2: But in the angels even of the one order there are first, middle, and last, as Dionysius says (Hier.
column3: But in the angels even of the one order there are first, middle, and last, as Dionysius says (Hier.

column2: Ang. x). Therefore the angels are not of the same species.
column3: Ang. x). Therefore the angels are not of the same species.

column2: _I answer that,_ Some have said that all spiritual substances, even souls, are of the one species.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore Some have said that all spiritual substances, even souls, are of the one species.

column2: Others, again, that all the angels are of the one species, but not souls; while others allege that all the angels of one hierarchy, or even of one order, are of the one species.
column3: Others, again, that all the angels are of the one species, but not souls; while others allege that all the angels of one hierarchy, or even of one order, are of the one species.

column2: But this is impossible.
column3: But this is impossible.

column2: For such things as agree in species but differ in number, agree in form, but are distinguished materially.
column3: For such things as agree in species but differ in number, agree in form, but are distinguished materially.

column2: If, therefore, the angels be not composed of matter and form, as was said above (A. 2), it follows that it is impossible for two angels to be of one species; just as it would be impossible for there to be several whitenesses apart, or several humanities, since whitenesses are not several, except in so far as they are in several substances. And if the angels had matter, not even then could there be several angels of one species.
column3: If, therefore, the angels be not composed of matter and form, as was said above (A. two), it follows that it is impossible for two angels to be of one species; just as it would be impossible for there to be several whitenesses apart, or several humanities, since whitenesses are not several, except in so far as they are in several substances. And if the angels had matter, not even then could there be several angels of one species.

column2: For it would be necessary for matter to be the principle of distinction of one from the other, not, indeed, according to the division of quantity, since they are incorporeal, but according to the diversity of their powers; and such diversity of matter causes diversity not merely of species, but of genus.
column3: For it would be necessary for matter to be the principle of distinction of one from the other, not, indeed, according to the division of quantity, since they are incorporeal, but according to the diversity of their powers; and such diversity of matter causes diversity not merely of species, but of genus.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: "Difference" is nobler than genus, as the determined is more noble than the undetermined, and the proper than the common, but not as one nature is nobler than another; otherwise it would be necessary that all irrational animals be of the same species; or that there should be in them some form which is higher than the sensible soul.
column3: Reply o b j. one: "Difference" is nobler than genus, as the determined is more noble than the undetermined, and the proper than the common, but not as one nature is nobler than another; otherwise it would be necessary that all irrational animals be of the same species; or that there should be in them some form which is higher than the sensible soul.

column2: Therefore irrational animals differ in species according to the various determined degrees of sensitive nature; and in like manner all the angels differ in species according to the diverse degrees of intellectual nature.
column3: Therefore irrational animals differ in species according to the various determined degrees of sensitive nature; and in like manner all the angels differ in species according to the diverse degrees of intellectual nature.

column2: Reply Obj. 2: More and less change the species, not according as they are caused by the intensity or remissness of one form, but according as they are caused by forms of diverse degrees; for instance, if we say that fire is more perfect than air: and in this way the angels are diversified according to more or less.
column3: Reply o b j. two: More and less change the species, not according as they are caused by the intensity or remissness of one form, but according as they are caused by forms of diverse degrees; for instance, if we say that fire is more perfect than air: and in this way the angels are diversified according to more or less.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: The good of the species preponderates over the good of the individual.
column3: Reply o b j. three: The good of the species preponderates over the good of the individual.

column2: Hence it is much better for the species to be multiplied in the angels than for individuals to be multiplied in the one species.
column3: Hence it is much better for the species to be multiplied in the angels than for individuals to be multiplied in the one species.

column2: Reply Obj. 4: Numerical multiplication, since it can be drawn out infinitely, is not intended by the agent, but only specific multiplication, as was said above (Q. 47, A. 3).
column3: Reply o b j. four: Numerical multiplication, since it can be drawn out infinitely, is not intended by the agent, but only specific multiplication, as was said above (Q. forty seven, a three).

column2: Hence the perfection of the angelic nature calls for the multiplying of species, but not for the multiplying of individuals in one species. _______________________
column3: Hence the perfection of the angelic nature calls for the multiplying of species, but not for the multiplying of individuals in one species. , blank ,

column2: FIFTH ARTICLE [I, Q. 50, Art.
column3: FIFTH ARTICLE [I, q fifty, Art.
five]

column2: Whether the Angels Are Incorruptible?
column3: Whether the Angels Are Incorruptible?

column2: Objection 1: It would seem that the angels are not incorruptible; for Damascene, speaking of the angel, says (De Fide Orth. ii, 3) that he is "an intellectual substance, partaking of immortality by favor, and not by nature."
column3: Objection one: It would seem that the angels are not incorruptible; for Damascene, speaking of the angel, says (De Fide Orth. ii, three) that he is "an intellectual substance, partaking of immortality by favor, and not by nature."

column2: Obj. 2: Further, Plato says in the Timaeus: "O gods of gods, whose maker and father am I: You are indeed my works, dissoluble by nature, yet indissoluble because I so will it." But gods such as these can only be understood to be the angels.
column3: o b j. two: Further, Plato says in the Timaeus: "O gods of gods, whose maker and father am I: You are indeed my works, dissoluble by nature, yet indissoluble because I so will it." But gods such as these can only be understood to be the angels.

column2: Therefore the angels are corruptible by their nature
column3: Therefore the angels are corruptible by their nature

column2: Obj. 3: Further, according to Gregory (Moral. xvi), "all things would tend towards nothing, unless the hand of the Almighty preserved them." But what can be brought to nothing is corruptible.
column3: o b j. three: Further, according to Gregory (Moral. x v i), "all things would tend towards nothing, unless the hand of the Almighty preserved them." But what can be brought to nothing is corruptible.

column2: Therefore, since the angels were made by God, it would appear that they are corruptible of their own nature.
column3: Therefore, since the angels were made by God, it would appear that they are corruptible of their own nature.

column2: _On the contrary,_ Dionysius says (Div.
column3: underscore On the contrary,underscore Dionysius says (d i v.

column2: Nom. iv) that the intellectual substances "have unfailing life, being free from all corruption, death, matter, and generation."
column3: Nom. i v) that the intellectual substances "have unfailing life, being free from all corruption, death, matter, and generation."

column2: _I answer that,_ It must necessarily be maintained that the angels are incorruptible of their own nature.
column3: underscore I answer that,underscore It must necessarily be maintained that the angels are incorruptible of their own nature.

column2: The reason for this is, that nothing is corrupted except by its form being separated from the matter.
column3: The reason for this is, that nothing is corrupted except by its form being separated from the matter.

column2: Hence, since an angel is a subsisting form, as is clear from what was said above (A. 2), it is impossible for its substance to be corruptible.
column3: Hence, since an angel is a subsisting form, as is clear from what was said above (A. two), it is impossible for its substance to be corruptible.

column2: For what belongs to anything considered in itself can never be separated from it; but what belongs to a thing, considered in relation to something else, can be separated, when that something else is taken away, in view of which it belonged to it.
column3: For what belongs to anything considered in itself can never be separated from it; but what belongs to a thing, considered in relation to something else, can be separated, when that something else is taken away, in view of which it belonged to it.

column2: Roundness can never be taken from the circle, because it belongs to it of itself; but a bronze circle can lose roundness, if the bronze be deprived of its circular shape.
column3: Roundness can never be taken from the circle, because it belongs to it of itself; but a bronze circle can lose roundness, if the bronze be deprived of its circular shape.

column2: Now to be belongs to a form considered in itself; for everything is an actual being according to its form: whereas matter is an actual being by the form.
column3: Now to be belongs to a form considered in itself; for everything is an actual being according to its form: whereas matter is an actual being by the form.

column2: Consequently a subject composed of matter and form ceases to be actually when the form is separated from the matter.
column3: Consequently a subject composed of matter and form ceases to be actually when the form is separated from the matter.

column2: But if the form subsists in its own being, as happens in the angels, as was said above (A. 2), it cannot lose its being. Therefore, the angel's immateriality is the cause why it is incorruptible by its own nature.
column3: But if the form subsists in its own being, as happens in the angels, as was said above (A. two), it cannot lose its being. Therefore, the angel's immateriality is the cause why it is incorruptible by its own nature.

column2: A token of this incorruptibility can be gathered from its intellectual operation; for since everything acts according as it is actual, the operation of a thing indicates its mode of being.
column3: A token of this incorruptibility can be gathered from its intellectual operation; for since everything acts according as it is actual, the operation of a thing indicates its mode of being.

column2: Now the species and nature of the operation is understood from the object.
column3: Now the species and nature of the operation is understood from the object.

column2: But an intelligible object, being above time, is everlasting.
column3: But an intelligible object, being above time, is everlasting.

column2: Hence every intellectual substance is incorruptible of its own nature.
column3: Hence every intellectual substance is incorruptible of its own nature.

column2: Reply Obj. 1: Damascene is dealing with perfect immortality, which includes complete immutability; since "every change is a kind of death," as Augustine says (Contra Maxim. iii).
column3: Reply o b j. one: Damascene is dealing with perfect immortality, which includes complete immutability; since "every change is a kind of death," as Augustine says (Contra Maxim. iii).

column2: The angels obtain perfect immutability only by favor, as will appear later (Q. 62).
column3: The angels obtain perfect immutability only by favor, as will appear later (Q. sixty two).

column2: Reply Obj. 2: By the expression 'gods' Plato understands the heavenly bodies, which he supposed to be made up of elements, and therefore dissoluble of their own nature; yet they are for ever preserved in existence by the Divine will.
column3: Reply o b j. two: By the expression 'gods' Plato understands the heavenly bodies, which he supposed to be made up of elements, and therefore dissoluble of their own nature; yet they are for ever preserved in existence by the Divine will.

column2: Reply Obj. 3: As was observed above (Q. 44, A. 1) there is a kind of necessary thing which has a cause of its necessity.
column3: Reply o b j. three: As was observed above (Q. forty four, a one) there is a kind of necessary thing which has a cause of its necessity.

column2: Hence it is not repugnant to a necessary or incorruptible being to depend for its existence on another as its cause.
column3: Hence it is not repugnant to a necessary or incorruptible being to depend for its existence on another as its cause.

column2: Therefore, when it is said that all things, even the angels, would lapse into nothing, unless preserved by God, it is not to be gathered therefrom that there is any principle of corruption in the angels; but that the nature of the angels is dependent upon God as its cause.
column3: Therefore, when it is said that all things, even the angels, would lapse into nothing, unless preserved by God, it is not to be gathered therefrom that there is any principle of corruption in the angels; but that the nature of the angels is dependent upon God as its cause.

column2: For a thing is said to be corruptible not merely because God can reduce it to non-existence, by withdrawing His act of preservation; but also because it has some principle of corruption within itself, or some contrariety, or at least the potentiality of matter. _______________________
column3: For a thing is said to be corruptible not merely because God can reduce it to non existence, by withdrawing His act of preservation; but also because it has some principle of corruption within itself, or some contrariety, or at least the potentiality of matter. , blank ,
